fp.title: Crossy Tractor (Research Park Hackathon 2023 2nd Place Overall)
fp.caption: Our home screen- in house graphics :)
fp.caption1: Our leaderboard of scores, deployed on MongoDB
fp.shortDes: This hackathon was hosted for all interns at the 120+ different companies based in Research Park, Champaign. The theme was to create a retro video game that encapsulated our company's themes in 16 hours. So in a team of five, we created Crossy Tractor, a remake of Crossy Road with some twists.
fp.longerDes: So to play our game, you can use the WASD keypad to control a combine, and the goal is to collect the corn while avoiding the runaway animals. Run into the animals three times, and you're out! I created a <bold>live leaderboard<bold> for our application using <bold>MongoDB<bold> and connected it to our frontend using <bold>Express<bold>. I also created some of the game logic in <bold>Pixi.js<bold> such as defining player movement and organizing the graphics drawn by our graphics team.

fp.title: Garbage Classification Model (HackIllinois 2023 Winner)
fp.caption: The front-end for our webapp
fp.caption1: Performing Image Segmentation on a jar to filter out background and get the jar's true color
fp.caption2: The images we stored on AWS S3 to train our model
fp.shortDes: This project won one of six grand prizes at HackIllinois 2023, UIUC's premiere hackathon with <bold>750 participants<bold> this year. Working in a team of 4, we created a web-app where the user can upload images or descriptions of their trash, and our program will classify the trash into one of six categories: glass, compost, paper, hazardous waste, plastic and soft metals, residual waste
fp.longerDes: I worked on the <bold>Computer Vision<bold> model for sorting the images of trash, Nancy worked on the frontend of our project, and Swathi + Robert worked on the Natural Language Processing Model for sorting descriptions of trash. I used <bold>AWS S3<bold> to store large sets of training images, and <bold>AWS EC2<bold> to train my <bold>Tensorflow Image Classification<bold> models to minimize the overhead on my computer. We also had to sort the glass bottles by color, so I used <bold>image segmentation<bold> to get the color of the glass. For our NLTK model, we used named entity recognition, <bold>neural networks<bold>, and synonyms to help our program understand the descriptions of trash.
